title: The Globalization Penalty
segmentation: Thank you very much.
I'm delighted to be able to present.
It's a very broad reaching topic.
You're wondering globalization penalty.
What in the world is this going to be about?

But if you'll bear with me, I'm going to walk through a couple of concepts to frame the presentation, explain a bit what this globalization penalty is, and then use search so international search engine optimization as an example of one of the ways that you can get that balance between global and local.
So McKinsey often does fantastic research.
I mean, these are some of the smartest people in the world, and I'll use two of their studies.
One is very interesting, 2011.
They've come out with a new study and it is their concept, not mine.
This idea of the globalization penalty and it's really quite simple.
They said they were a bit perplexed that strong multinational companies seemed less healthy and there are a whole host of ways in which they are less healthy.
But they seem certainly less successful.
Then local companies that were sticking close to home and they ask themselves how can that be?
I mean our concept that multilingual global companies are better has been with us for some time, but they named this phenomenon.
The globalization.
Lt and the idea that global is better, I wanted to stick with the theme of Rome, so this is actually a photo I took on the outside of the Colosseum Monday afternoon.
You look at the spread of the Roman Empire at its height, but you can even consider the Venetian traders in the 10th century as being truly representative of a global far flung enterprise.
And we this concept is with us that somehow global is better.
We can leverage our strengths and that we must be able to do more.
But some things don't go away in this concept that there's complexity.
Local firms are more nimble, they're more agile.
They respond better to the local market.
The McKinsey study is very interesting.
I've referenced it in the deck and you can go online and get it.

Everything from the way multinationals value talent or don't value local talent the way they try to centralized functions versus decentralized, and McKinsey zeroed in on three functions that they felt were particularly problematic.
So there was the concept of human resource is many of you may have seen their charts that link high context cultures and high context professions.
And HR is such a high context profession.
One can understand why it's best to do that locally.
Finance, no comment.
That's the other side of the equation.
But marketing in all of its definition was another function that was deemed to be difficult to centralise.
Is this really a surprise for any of us in the room?

I mean, to some extent it feels like the Wayback Machine where we're talking about this balance between global and local, but they interviewed 500 firms they talked to 20 champions and these are CEOs, heads of multinational corporations.
You can read some of the research and they talked to 600,000 different employees, so it's quite thorough.
The research that was done.
Again, it comes back to the very simple essence that when you get global, you introduce complexity.
Complexity is cost, it's burden, it's overhead and therefore global multinational companies need to really understand what of being global is a benefit and what is perhaps your globalization penalty.
And again, balance central versus local.
I mean, does this discussion ever get old?
So now I'd like.

Jump in and discuss a bit more about zeroing in on the area of marketing because this is one that clearly is tense between global and local control, and I'd like to link that to one of the essences of the McKinsey.
Study is find out something that you do well and capitalize on that in a very local way, and what could be more emblematic of that than doing local search really well.
So I'd like to walk you through another framework.
Each is one that came out in 2009 an it's called the Consumer decision journey.
Has anyone in the audience read this, either the McKinsey article or the Harvard business reviewed paper that they authored later?
We have one.

This is a great piece of work, especially for all of us working internationally because it really shows the difference between the way that we used to consider products we used to buy and what's happening now, and I'll try to condense it into a few short ideas we used to systematically winnow down information we would often do this face to face.
We would shop.
We would go look, kick tires, whatever you have, but the premise is that we are now doing all of that, predominantly in a digital environment.
In a digital way, how many of you in the audience have purchased a small home appliance?
Maybe something for your kitchen laundry, some type of equipment, coffee maker, anything in the last six months?
How many of you did your research anew?
Which item which product you were going to buy before you went into the store to actually purchase it?
This is the essence of the McKinsey article that branding in a digital.
Age is very, very different and that this is the reason I believe this is important.
I will show you because we have all grown up in a very different world.
We've grown up in a world where it's my idea as a publisher.
It is my brand management as a company.
It is my information, Datasheet, project, product spec sheet, what have you that I will push out to the consumer and I will define your perception of my service or product by doing so.

It's very linear, it's very controlled and it is totally inappropriate for today's world because as a younger consumer I don't care what you say about your product or what you're publishing or pushing because I am going to go seek, I'm going to pull my own information, so that's the second part of the McKinsey premise is that all of the marketing that matters.
We heard from Verisign.
Whether it's trusted content, whether it comes from a social network, but all of the content that influences our decisions.
Is actually consumer driven marketing, which means I'm going to search for it and I'm going to find what I want.
And so, as I mentioned a moment ago, we have most of us in the room grown up in this world.
Very linear ipublish I push, I refresh, I do it again, but I control the message.
And this is it.
Relevant in today's world and you see the graphic before you.
Now this is the McKinsey premise again, that it is a journey and it's cyclical.
There are a couple of important touchpoints.
There are four of them, but the one that I've circled here is that moment of active evaluation.
I too bought a small appliance.
I bought a Nespresso lattissima machine.

I think it's incredible.

Means you may have done something on your website in trying to boost your search results or improve your rankings and presence that is felt to be not fair play and you are now on the naughty list.

OK, so there are rules and then there are rules.

So one of the things that we've zeroed in on is that idea of this global customer lifecycle.
You're not mistaken.
It Maps exactly to the McKinsey article I just referenced.
We've made this the backdrop for everything that we're doing at our company, but today I'm going to focus just on that topic.
I promised, which is about search.
What happens when people seek for information?
What are we seeing in the marketplace that people are doing well?
What could people do better and what's really exciting as we look out to the future?
So this is how you can change the rules.
Be global, but win on the local search playing field.

The whole global customer lifecycle, because as I mentioned, 71% of potential customers are deciding which company to buy from or what product to purchase based on either search in their language or peer input that they get from forums, forums, and trusted sources.
This is an enormous shift in our lifetime, in the way that people are influenced.
I won't talk about some of the other points as I said.
On the customer lifecycle, but we could do just as much of a deep dive on support on the handling of support.
Customer experience, how people engage, how they buy, but today will go down now more of a path on search.
The three biggest problems that we see when we talk with our customers when we meet prospects.
It's remarkable how similar the issues are, and they're pretty simple and they are business issues.
These are not translation issues.
These are not language service provider issues.
These are I don't have enough traffic.
Sadly, I may have already translated my site, paid money, but I'm getting only 60 page views in Italian, so we're thinking of shutting it down.

Very low search engine page rankings and for example I have a client that is one of the world's dominant cruise lines and.
They are number one for the word cruise and non branded term in the US.
They don't even appear in the top 100 in any of the other global markets.
This is this is an example of a globalization penalty in thinking about their own market they missed the boat and the cruise industry is shifting entirely.
The cruise industry is is viewed to be over 55% now non North American.
That's an enormous shift for an industry that was very North American and.
It's moving to Asia, the two largest cruise ships in the world have been delivered to Shanghai, so this is a business problem for this customer.
The second problem we have is really what we call it the walk phase.
I've done the right things.
I've translated it, but I'm not getting enough conversions, so this becomes a money issue.

There are a lot of differing opinions about whether pursuing long tail keywords pays off or does not.

Personally, in the work that we've done, we found that if you do the right research, if we clean up some of the long tail phrasing, so again, general phrases, high competition, high cost, unbranded keywords in the middle of this curve, you have some more specific phrases, but down at the long tail you've got these multi segment searches and the theory being that the sum of the long tail searches is greater than the highly competitive general phrases, and that may be true.
But there is also a lot of junk in there and you don't want negative keywords generating expensive clicks that you're paying for.
There are ways to do this.
And there are ways that we can go through reducing the number of keywords.

Again, it comes down to the research, the expertise of the people in the country, grouping keywords and thinking about the ad text in the landing pages that are going to go with any of these long tail words that you come up with.
We've seen a lot of companies salivating over the long tail, so think about this rather than 100 keywords that you're managing, its thousands and thousands of keywords.

Look at that, research the keywords, reduce them down, throw out the negative group them in a way that's less expensive and costly for the customer, and then monitor, monitor, monitor, issue those benchmark reports you know every day if we need to.
So we've really learned by the numbers.
I mean, this is not trivial where we have 1.5 million web pages that we manage that sit on our server.
We're managing everything from global campaigns to the rollout of products in hundreds of countries, and we know that this makes a difference.

Personally, in the work that we've done, we found that if you do the right research, if we clean up some of the long tail phrasing, so again, general phrases, high competition, high cost, unbranded keywords in the middle of this curve, you have some more specific phrases, but down at the long tail you've got these multi segment searches and the theory being that the sum of the long tail searches is greater than the highly competitive general phrases, and that may be true.
But there is also a lot of junk in there and you don't want negative keywords generating expensive clicks that you're paying for.
There are ways to do this.
And there are ways that we can go through reducing the number of keywords.

Again, it comes down to the research, the expertise of the people in the country, grouping keywords and thinking about the ad text in the landing pages that are going to go with any of these long tail words that you come up with.
We've seen a lot of companies salivating over the long tail, so think about this rather than 100 keywords that you're managing, its thousands and thousands of keywords.
